cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 153 (Thursday, September 21, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. FITZGERALD:H.R. 5632.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:clause 18 of section 8 of article I of the Constitution.The single subject of this legislation is:This bill directs the Administrator of USAID to maketraining available to non-adversarial governments onassessing, analyzing, and mitigating the risk of adversarialgovernment lending.[Page H4457]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

cdata.text:
Thwarting Regional Adversary Investments Now Act or TRAIN Act

This bill requires the U.S. Agency for International Development to make training available to appropriate government officials of non-adversarial countries in South and Central Asia on analyzing, assessing, and mitigating any legal or financial risk of accepting investment or lending from a foreign adversary that is in the region.

bill.title: Thwarting Regional Adversary Investments Now Act

item.title: Thwarting Regional Adversary Investments Now Act
Thwarting Regional Adversary Investments Now Act

To direct the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development to make available to government officials of nonadversarial countries in South and Central Asia training in analyzing, assessing, and mitigating any risk of accepting investment or lending from China, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
